Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: I was sitting on the edge of my bed, my phone buzzing in my hand. My stepbrother’s voice still echoed in my mind—he’d just called, barely able to speak through his tears. The news about his mom’s health had hit him hard, and I knew he needed me. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to comfort him, to show that he wasn’t alone. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart pounded faster. The polls would close in less than an hour, and this was my only chance to vote. My wallet, with my ID, was in my car, parked at the polling station across town. I could hear my stepbrother’s sobs in my memory, but I also felt the weight of my civic duty pressing on me. I was expected to support him, but I was also expected to fulfill my responsibility as a voter. My hands shook as I tried to decide which role to answer first, feeling the impossible pull of both expectations.
